Right now I train my network on a single set of input data. After reaching =
a predefined fitness value I switch over to the next set of input data. Whe=
n the fitness is too low the training begins for this data and continues un=
til the predefined fitness value is reached and so on.
After a few iteratio=
ns the network produces perfect outputs on some sets of data. Consequently =
the best fitness value is extremly high. When I now switch to a new set of =
data it's nearly impossible to reach this fitness and so the best genome wi=
ll never change again, even if it performs really bad on different inputs.
=
My idea was that I could reset the best fitness each time when I change the=
 input data. The data is changed within the EvaluateNetwork method; is ther=
e also a way to reset the best fitness from within this method? Or should I=
 better change the whole workflow?

Cheers,
Daniel

--- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, "Daniel" <daniel_kuppitz@...> wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I have =
a general question regarding the learning process.
> 
> After playing aroun=
d with NERO the last days, I've learned a lot about how networks learn, but=
 I still found no answer to this elementary question: In which sequence sho=
uld I train a network that has to solve more than one task. NERO isn't buil=
d with HyperNEAT, but I think my questions target HyperNEAT as well as NEAT=
.
> 
> Consider 9 stages:
> 
> Network is ...
> 
>   1: quite good in task =
#1
>   2: really good in task #1
>   3: perfect in task #1
>   4: quite goo=
d in task #2
>   5: really good in task #2
>   6: perfect in task #2
>   7:=
 quite good in task #1 and #2
>   8: really good in task #1 and #2
>   9: p=
erfect in task #1 and #2
> 
> Obviously I'll begin with stage 1, but what's=
 next? Should I continue to train my network in this task (continue with st=
age 2) or should I switch to the next task (stage 4/7) and come back to sta=
ge 2 later.
> The next question is: How should I calculate the fitness when=
 the network is trained in task #2.  Should solutions for task #2 be reward=
ed higher than those for task #1 (stage 4) or should solutions for task #1 =
still get the same reward as in stage 1 (stage 7)?
> 
> Maybe there's no ge=
neral answer to my questions, but what's the best practice? What makes sens=
e, what does not?
> 
> Cheers,
> Daniel
>
